english_text: So rainfall and the recycling of organic matter are two of the factors that keep the rain forest standing and growing.

english_text: In view of the prophetic nature and highly symbolic language of this book, theadjective“apocalyptic” came to be applied to a form of literature that began long before the Bible book of Revelation was written.

english_text: Tinysensorsattached to three alpine swifts at their breeding site have shown that the birds flew nonstop for more than 200 days while migrating to Africa.

yoruba_text: Ohun tó máa ṣẹlẹ̀ sí ìjọba èèyàn túbọ̀ ń ṣe kedere bá yìí tó jẹ́ pé ọ̀pọ̀ à wọn alá kòóso ti fi hàn pé à wọn jẹ́ 'olùfẹ́ ara wọn, olùfẹ́ owó, ajọra-ẹni-lójú, onírera, alá ìdúróṣinṣin, alá ìṣeé bá ṣe à déhùn kankan, afọ̀rọ̀-èké-banijẹ́, alá ìní ìkóra-ẹni-níjà ánu, òǹrorò, alá ìní ìfẹ́ ohun rere, afinihàn à ti awúfùkẹ̀ pẹ̀lú ìgbéraga.'—2 Tím.
english_text: The failure of man's rule is especially evident today when so many rulers have shown themselves to be 'lovers of themselves, lovers of money, self-assuming, haughty, disloyal, not open to any agreement, slanderers, without self-control, fierce, without love of goodness, betrayers, and puffed up with pride.' —2 Tim.

yoruba_text: Níto rí à wọn ènìyàn yóò jẹ́ olùfẹ́ ara wọn,... ajọra-ẹni-lójú, onírera,... alá ìlọ́pẹ́, alá ìdúróṣinṣin, alá ìní ìfẹ́ni à dá nidá, alá ìṣeé bá ṣe à déhùn kankan, afọ̀rọ̀-èké-banijẹ́, alá ìní ìkóra-ẹni-níjà ánu, òǹrorò, alá ìní ìfẹ́ ohun rere, afinihàn, olùwarùnkì, awúfùkẹ̀ pẹ̀lú ìgbéraga, olùfẹ́ adùn dípò olùfẹ́ Ọlọ́run, à wọn tí wọ́n ní ìrísí fífọkà nsin Ọlọ́run ṣùgbọ́n tí wọ́n já sí èké ní ti agbá ra rẹ̀.”—2 Tímótì 3:1-5.
english_text: For men will be lovers of themselves,... self-assuming, haughty,... unthankful, disloyal, having no natural affection, not open to any agreement, slanderers, without self-control, fierce, without love of goodness, betrayers, headstrong, puffed up with pride, lovers of pleasures rather than lovers of God, having a form of godly devotion but proving false to its power.” —2 Timothy 3:1-5.

yoruba_text: Ó sọ à wọn nǹkan tó mú kí à wọn à kókò náà “nira lá ti bá lò,” ó ní: “Àwọn ènìyàn yóò jẹ́ olùfẹ́ ara wọn, olùfẹ́ owó, ajọra-ẹni-lójú, onírera, asọ̀rọ̀ òdì, aṣà ìgbọràn sí òbí, alá ìlọ́pẹ́, alá ìdúróṣinṣin, alá ìní ìfẹ́ni à dá nidá, alá ìṣeé bá ṣe à déhùn kankan, afọ̀rọ̀-èké-banijẹ́, alá ìní ìkóra-ẹni-níjà ánu, òǹrorò, alá ìní ìfẹ́ ohun rere, afinihàn, olùwarùnkì, awúfùkẹ̀ pẹ̀lú ìgbéraga, olùfẹ́ adùn dípò olùfẹ́ Ọlọ́run, à wọn tí wọ́n ní ìrísí fífọkà nsin Ọlọ́run ṣùgbọ́n tí wọ́n já sí èké ní ti agbá ra rẹ̀; yà kúrò lọ́dọ̀ à wọn wọ̀nyí pẹ̀lú.”—2 Tímótì 3:1-5.
english_text: To show what makes the days “hard to deal with,” it goes on to say: “Men will be lovers of themselves, lovers of money, self-assuming, haughty, blasphemers, disobedient to parents, unthankful, disloyal, having no natural affection, not open to any agreement, slanderers, without self-control, fierce, without love of goodness, betrayers, headstrong, puffed up with pride, lovers of pleasures rather than lovers of God, having a form of godly devotion but proving false to its power; and from these turn away.” —2 Timothy 3:1-5.

yoruba_text: Fún à pẹẹrẹ, fi à wọn ìsọtẹ́lẹ̀ tí a mẹ́nu kàn lókè yí wé ohun tí Bíbélì sọ ní nǹkan bí 20 ọ̀rúndún sẹ́yìn nípa ọjọ́ wa: “Àwọn ènìyàn yóò jẹ́ olùfẹ́ ara wọn, olùfẹ́ owó, ajọra-ẹni-lójú, onírera, asọ̀rọ̀-òdì, aṣà ìgbọràn sí òbí, alá ìlọ́pẹ́, alá ìdúróṣinṣin, alá ìní ìfẹ́ni à dá nidá, alá ìṣeé bá ṣe à déhùn kankan, afọ̀rọ̀-èké-banijẹ́, alá ìní ìkóra-ẹni-níjà ánu, òǹrorò, alá ìní ìfẹ́ ohun rere, afinihàn, olùwarùnkì, awúfùkẹ̀ pẹ̀lú ìgbéraga, olùfẹ́ adùn dípò olùfẹ́ Ọlọ́run, à wọn tí wọ́n ní à wòr án ìrísí ìfọkà nsin Ọlọ́run ṣùgbọ́n tí wọ́n já sí èké ní ti agbá ra rẹ̀.”—Tímótì Kejì 3:1-5.
english_text: For example, compare the foregoing predictions with what the Bible foretold almost 20 centuries ago in regard to our day: “Men will be lovers of themselves, lovers of money, self-assuming, haughty, blasphemers, disobedient to parents, unthankful, disloyal, having no natural affection, not open to any agreement, slanderers, without self-control, fierce, without love of goodness, betrayers, headstrong, puffed up with pride, lovers of pleasures rather than lovers of God, having a form of godly devotion but proving false to its power.”—2 Timothy 3:1-5.

yoruba_text: Ó mú kí á mọ̀ pé ní ọjọ́ wa, à wọn ènìyàn yóò jẹ́ “olùfẹ́ ara wọn,... ajọra-ẹni-lójú, onírera,... alá ìlọ́pẹ́, alá ìdúróṣinṣin, alá ìní ìfẹ́ni à dá nidá, alá ìṣeé bá ṣe à déhùn kankan, afọ̀rọ̀-èké-banijẹ́,... afinihàn, olùwarùnkì, awúfùkẹ̀ pẹlu ìgbéraga.”
english_text: It made known that in our day people would be “lovers of themselves,... self-assuming, haughty,... unthankful, disloyal, having no natural affection, not open to any agreement, slanderers,... betrayers, headstrong, puffed up with pride.”

english_text: God's Word, the Bible, foretold that in our time people would be “self-assuming, haughty.”

yoruba_text: Níto rí à wọn ènìyàn yóò jẹ́ olùfẹ́ ara wọn, olùfẹ́ owó, ajọra-ẹni-lójú, onírera, asọ̀rọ̀ òdì, aṣà ìgbọràn sí òbí, alá ìlọ́pẹ́, alá ìdúróṣinṣin, alá ìní ìfẹ́ni à dá nidá, alá ìṣeé bá ṣe à déhùn kankan, afọ̀rọ̀-èké-banijẹ́, alá ìní ìkóra-ẹni-níjà ánu, òǹrorò, alá ìní ìfẹ́ ohun rere, afinihàn, olùwarùnkì, awúfùkẹ̀ pẹ̀lú ìgbéraga, olùfẹ́ adùn dípò olùfẹ́ Ọlọ́run, à wọn tí wọ́n ní ìrísí fífọkà nsin Ọlọ́run ṣùgbọ́n tí wọ́n já sí èké ní ti agbá ra rẹ̀; yà kúrò lọ́dọ̀ à wọn wọ̀nyí pẹ̀lú.
english_text: For men will be lovers of themselves, lovers of money, self-assuming, haughty, blasphemers, disobedient to parents, unthankful, disloyal, having no natural affection, not open to any agreement, slanderers, without self-control, fierce, without love of goodness, betrayers, headstrong, puffed up with pride, lovers of pleasures rather than lovers of God, having a form of godly devotion but proving false to its power; and from these turn away.

yoruba_text: (Má tíù 24:12) Àpọ́sítélì Pọ́ọ̀lù sọ ohun kan tó fara jọ ìyẹn náà nígbà tó kọ̀wé pé: “Àwọn ènìyàn yóò jẹ́ olùfẹ́ ara wọn, olùfẹ́ owó, ajọra-ẹni-lójú, onírera, asọ̀rọ̀ òdì, aṣà ìgbọràn sí òbí, alá ìlọ́pẹ́, alá ìdúróṣinṣin, alá ìní ìfẹ́ni à dá nidá [tà bí, lá àárín ẹbí], alá ìṣeé bá ṣe à déhùn kankan, afọ̀rọ̀-èké-banijẹ́, alá ìní ìkóra-ẹni-níjà ánu, òǹrorò, alá ìní ìfẹ́ ohun rere, afinihàn, olùwarùnkì, awúfùkẹ̀ pẹ̀lú ìgbéraga, olùfẹ́ adùn dípò olùfẹ́ Ọlọ́run.”
english_text: (Matthew 24:12) In a similar vein, the apostle Paul wrote: “[People] will be lovers of themselves, lovers of money, self-assuming, haughty, blasphemers, disobedient to parents, unthankful, disloyal, having no natural [or, familial] affection, not open to any agreement, slanderers, without self-control, fierce, without love of goodness, betrayers, headstrong, puffed up with pride, lovers of pleasures rather than lovers of God.”

yoruba_text: Níto rí à wọn ènìyàn yóò jẹ́ olùfẹ́ araawọn, olùfẹ́ owó, ajọra-ẹni lójú, onírera, asọ̀rọ̀-òdì, aṣà ìgbọ́ràn sí òbí, alá ìlọ́pẹ́, alá ìdúróṣinṣin, alá ìní-ìfẹ́ni-à dánidá, alá ìṣeé bá ṣe à déhùn, afọ̀rọ̀-èké-banijẹ́, alá ìní ìkóra-ẹni-níjà ánu, òǹrorò, alá ìní ìfẹ́ ohun rere, afinihàn, olùwarùnkì, awúfùkẹ̀ pẹ̀lú ìgbéraga, olùfẹ́ adùn dípò olùfẹ́ Ọlọrun, à wọn tí wọn ní à wòr án ìrísí ìfọkà nsin Ọlọrun, ṣùgbọ́n tí wọn já sí èké níti agbá ra rẹ̀.”
english_text: For men will be lovers of themselves, lovers of money, self-assuming, haughty, blasphemers, disobedient to parents, unthankful, disloyal, having no natural affection, not open to any agreement, slanderers, without self-control, fierce, without love of goodness, betrayers, headstrong, puffed up with pride, lovers of pleasures rather than lovers of God, having a form of godly devotion but proving false to its power.”

yoruba_text: (Má tíù 24:7-14; Lúùkù 21:11) Ayé yìí kún fọ́fọ́ fún à wọn ènìyàn tí ó jẹ́ “jẹ́ olùfẹ́ ara wọn, olùfẹ́ owó, ajọra-ẹni-lójú, onírera, asọ̀rọ̀ òdì, aṣà ìgbọràn sí òbí, alá ìlọ́pẹ́, alá ìdúróṣinṣin, alá ìní ìfẹ́ni à dá nidá, alá ìṣeé bá ṣe à déhùn kankan, afọ̀rọ̀-èké-banijẹ́, alá ìní ìkóra-ẹni-níjà ánu, òǹrorò, alá ìní ìfẹ́ ohun rere, afinihàn, olùwarùnkì, awúfùkẹ̀ pẹ̀lú ìgbéraga, olùfẹ́ adùn dípò olùfẹ́ Ọlọ́run.”
english_text: (Matthew 24:7-14; Luke 21:11) The world is full of those who are “lovers of themselves, lovers of money, self-assuming, haughty, blasphemers, disobedient to parents, unthankful, disloyal, having no natural affection, not open to any agreement, slanderers, without self-control, fierce, without love of goodness, betrayers, headstrong, puffed up with pride, lovers of pleasures rather than lovers of God.”

yoruba_text: Níto rí à wọn ènìyàn yóò jẹ́ olùfẹ́ ara wọn, olùfẹ́ owó, ajọra-ẹni-lójú, onírera, asọ̀rọ̀ òdì, aṣà ìgbọràn sí òbí, alá ìlọ́pẹ́, alá ìdúróṣinṣin, alá ìní ìfẹ́ni à dá nidá, alá ìṣeé bá ṣe à déhùn kankan, afọ̀rọ̀-èké-banijẹ́, alá ìní ìkóra-ẹni-níjà ánu, òǹrorò, alá ìní ìfẹ́ ohun rere, afinihàn, olùwarùnkì, awúfùkẹ̀ pẹ̀lú ìgbéraga, olùfẹ́ adùn dípò olùfẹ́ Ọlọ́run, à wọn tí wọ́n ní ìrísí fífọkà nsin Ọlọ́run ṣùgbọ́n tí wọ́n já sí èké ní ti agbá ra rẹ̀; yà kúrò lọ́dọ̀ à wọn wọ̀nyí pẹ̀lú.” —2 Tím.
english_text: For men will be lovers of themselves, lovers of money, boastful, haughty, blasphemers, disobedient to parents, unthankful, disloyal, having no natural affection, not open to any agreement, slanderers, without self-control, fierce, without love of goodness, betrayers, headstrong, puffed up with pride, lovers of pleasures rather than lovers of God, having an appearance of godliness but proving false to its power; and from these turn away.” —2 Tim.

yoruba_text: Torí à wọn èèyàn máa nífẹ̀ẹ́ ara wọn nìkan, wọ́n á nífẹ̀ẹ́ owó, wọ́n á jẹ́ afọ́nnu, agbéraga, asọ̀rọ̀ òdì, aṣà ìgbọràn sí òbí, alá ìmoore, alá ìṣòótọ́, ẹni tí kò ní ìfẹ́ à dá mọ́ni, kìígbọ́-kìígbà, abanijẹ́, ẹni tí kò lè kó ara rẹ̀ níjà ánu, ẹni tó burú gan-an, ẹni tí kò nífẹ̀ẹ́ ohun rere, ọ̀dà lẹ̀, alá gídí, ajọra-ẹni-lójú, wọ́n á fẹ́ràn ìgbá dùn dípò Ọlọ́run, wọ́n á jọ ẹni tó ń sin Ọlọ́run tọkà ntọkàn, à mọ́ ìṣe wọn ò ní fi agbá ra rẹ̀ hàn.”
english_text: For men will be lovers of themselves, lovers of money, boastful, haughty, blasphemers, disobedient to parents, unthankful, disloyal, having no natural affection, not open to any agreement, slanderers, without self-control, fierce, without love of goodness, betrayers, headstrong, puffed up with pride, lovers of pleasures rather thanloversof God, having an appearance of godliness but proving false to its power.”

yoruba_text: BÍBÉLÌ sọ tẹ́lẹ̀ pé ní ọjọ́ wa, à wọn ènìyàn yóò jẹ́ “olùfẹ́ ara wọn, olùfẹ́ owó, ajọra-ẹni-lójú, onírera, asọ̀rọ̀-òdì, aṣà ìgbọràn sí òbí, alá ìlọ́pẹ́, alá ìdúróṣinṣin, alá ìní ìfẹ́ni à dá nidá, alá ìṣeé bá ṣe à déhùn kankan, afọ̀rọ̀-èké-banijẹ́, alá ìní ìkóra-ẹni-níjà ánu, òǹrorò, alá ìní ìfẹ́ ohun rere.”
english_text: THE Bible foretold that in our day people would be “lovers of themselves, lovers of money, self-assuming, haughty, blasphemers, disobedient to parents, unthankful, disloyal, having no natural affection, not open to any agreement, slanderers, without self-control, fierce, without love of goodness.”

yoruba_text: 2 Tímótì 3:1-5: “Ní à wọn ọjọ́ ìkẹyìn..., à wọn ènìyàn yóò jẹ́ olùfẹ́ ara wọn, olùfẹ́ owó, ajọra-ẹni-lójú, onírera, asọ̀rọ̀ òdì, aṣà ìgbọràn sí òbí, alá ìlọ́pẹ́, alá ìdúróṣinṣin, alá ìní ìfẹ́ni à dá nidá, alá ìṣeé bá ṣe à déhùn kankan, afọ̀rọ̀-èké-banijẹ́, alá ìní ìkóra-ẹni-níjà ánu, òǹrorò, alá ìní ìfẹ́ ohun rere, afinihàn, olùwarùnkì, awúfùkẹ̀ pẹ̀lú ìgbéraga, olùfẹ́ adùn dípò olùfẹ́ Ọlọ́run, à wọn tí wọ́n ní ìrísí fífọkà nsin Ọlọ́run ṣùgbọ́n tí wọ́n já sí èké ní ti agbá ra rẹ̀.”
english_text: 2 Timothy 3:1-5: “In the last days..., men will be lovers ofthemselves, lovers of money, boastful, haughty, blasphemers, disobedient to parents, unthankful, disloyal, having no natural affection, not open to any agreement, slanderers, without self-control, fierce, without love of goodness, betrayers, headstrong, puffed up with pride, lovers of pleasures rather than lovers of God, having an appearance of godliness but proving false to its power.”

yoruba_text: Bí ọ̀pọ̀ èèyàn ṣe jẹ́ajọra-ẹni-lójú, onígbèéraga à ti olùwarùnkì lá kòókò òpin tá à ń gbé yìí kì í ṣe ìwà ẹni tó ní là ákàyè rá rá.—2 Tímótì 3:1-5.
english_text: Theself-assuming, haughty, and headstrong spirit of people in these last days is not a manifestation of common sense. —2 Timothy 3:1-5.

yoruba_text: Bíbélì sọ tẹ́lẹ̀ pé lá kòókò tá à ń gbé yìí, ọ̀pọ̀ èèyàn á jẹ́ “olùfẹ́ ara wọn, olùfẹ́ owó, ajọra-ẹni-lójú, onírera,... alá ìlọ́pẹ́, alá ìdúróṣinṣin, alá ìní ìfẹ́ni à dá nidá, alá ìṣeé bá ṣe à déhùn kankan, afọ̀rọ̀-èké-banijẹ́, alá ìní ìkóra-ẹni-níjà ánu, òǹrorò, alá ìní ìfẹ́ ohun rere, afinihàn, olùwarùnkì, awúfùkẹ̀ pẹ̀lú ìgbéraga.”
english_text: The Bible predicted that many people in our time would be “lovers of themselves, lovers of money, self-assuming, haughty,... unthankful, disloyal, having no natural affection, not open to any agreement, slanderers, without self-control, fierce, without love of goodness, betrayers, headstrong, puffed up with pride.”

yoruba_text: 3 Gẹ́gẹ́ bí Bíbélì ti sọ tẹ́lẹ̀, ní à wọn ọjọ́ ìkẹyìn ètò à wọn nǹkan búburú yìí, ọ̀pọ̀ jẹ́ “olùfẹ́ ara wọn, olùfẹ́ owó, ajọra-ẹni-lójú, onírera, asọ̀rọ̀ òdì, aṣà ìgbọràn sí òbí, alá ìlọ́pẹ́, alá ìdúróṣinṣin, alá ìní ìfẹ́ni à dá nidá, alá ìṣeé bá ṣe à déhùn kankan, afọ̀rọ̀-èké-banijẹ́, alá ìní ìkóra-ẹni-níjà ánu, òǹrorò, alá ìní ìfẹ́ ohun rere, afinihàn, olùwarùnkì, awúfùkẹ̀ pẹ̀lú ìgbéraga, olùfẹ́ adùn dípò olùfẹ́ Ọlọ́run.”
english_text: 3 As Bible prophecy foretold, in these last days of this wicked system of things, many are “lovers of themselves, lovers of money, self-assuming, haughty, blasphemers, disobedient to parents, unthankful, disloyal, having no natural affection, not open to any agreement, slanderers, without self-control, fierce, without love of goodness, betrayers, headstrong, puffed up with pride, lovers of pleasures rather than lovers of God.”

yoruba_text: Àbí ẹ ò rí i bá wọn ọkùnrinajọra-ẹni-lójú yẹn á ṣe máa joró tó nígbà tí wọ́n ń gbọ́ tá wọn èèyàn Ọlọ́run kéde ní gbangba pé kì í ṣe pé wọ́n kùnà lá ti ṣamọ̀nà à wọn agbo wọn lọ sí ọ̀run nìkan ni ṣùgbọ́n à wọn fúnra wọn ò ní í débẹ̀!
english_text: How theseself-assumingmen must have been tormented at hearing it publicly announced that not only were they failing to lead their flocks to heaven but they themselves would not get there!

yoruba_text: Bó tilẹ̀ jẹ́ pé à wọn Ẹlẹ́rìí kì í ṣeajọra-ẹni-lójú tà bí olódodo lójú ara ẹni, wọ́n gbà gbọ́ pé bí gbogbo èèyàn bá ń tẹ̀ lé à wọn ìlà nà wọ̀nyí, ayé yìí á dùn á sì lá rinrin.
english_text: Though the Witnesses are notsmugorself-righteous, they believe that if everyone applied these principles, the world would be a much better place in which to live.

yoruba_text: (Tímótì Kejì 3:1-5) Ní kí kọ èrò tí ó fìdí múlẹ̀ nípa ìwà funfun, ìwà rere, orúkọ rere, à ti ìlà nà ìwà híhù sílẹ̀, ọ̀pọ̀ ti diajọra-ẹni-lójú nínú ìrònú wọn, wọ́n sì ti “ré kọjá gbogbo agbá ra òye ìwà rere.”
english_text: (2 Timothy 3:1-5) Rejecting traditional ideas about virtue, morality, honor, and ethics, many have becomeself-centered in their thinking and are “past all moral sense.”

yoruba_text: aka ọlọ́pọ́n
english_text: clipboard

yoruba_text: akalamagbo
english_text: hornbill

yoruba_text: Òwe kan tó jẹ mọ́ à ṣà oúnjẹ jíjẹ nínú ilé à wọn ẹ̀yàAkansọ pé: “Ọmọ tó bá mọ ọwọ́ wẹ̀ á bá à gbà jẹun.”
english_text: A proverb alluding to the traditional dining practice in a typical Akanhome states: “A child who learns to wash his hands eats with his elders.”

yoruba_text: Bí à pẹẹrẹ, nígbà tí ẹnì kan tó jẹ́ ẹ̀yàAkanbá ń sọ̀rọ̀ nípa ẹnì kan tó jẹ́ onírẹ̀lẹ̀ à ti ẹlẹ́mìí à là áfíà, ó lè sọ pé: “Bá a bá fi dá ti Lá gb ájá nìkan, kò ní sí ìró ìbọn kan ṣoṣo nínú abúlé yìí.”
english_text: Concerning a humble and peace-loving person, for example, an Akanmight say: “If it depended on So-and-so alone, there would be no gunshot in this village.”

yoruba_text: Àìgbọlọ́rungbọ́ kò sí nínú ìgbà gbọ́ à wọn ẹ̀yàAkan.
english_text: Atheistic ideas have no place in Akanphilosophy.

yoruba_text: Bí à pẹẹrẹ, ní à wùjọ à wọn ẹ̀yàAkan, ìwà à rífín ló jẹ́ lá ti máa lo ọwọ́ òsì níwá jú à wọn ẹlòmíràn, pà ápàá à wọn à gbà lagbà.
english_text: For example, among the Akanit is considered bad manners to gesture with the left hand before others, especially older ones.

yoruba_text: Ní à wùjọ à wọn ẹ̀yàAkan, lílo òwe lọ́nà jíjá fáfá jẹ́ à mì pé ẹnì kan jẹ́ amòye èèyàn.
english_text: In Akansociety, skill in the use of proverbs is a hallmark of wisdom.

yoruba_text: Ní à wùjọ à wọn ẹ̀yàAkan, à wọn aṣojú tà bí à wọn agbẹnusọ fún à wọn alá kòóso ìbílẹ̀ máa ń mọ òwe lò dá rad ára, wọ́n sì tún máa ń mú ọ̀pá à ṣẹ dá ní, èyí tí wọ́n ti ṣe iṣẹ́ ọnà sí lá ra lá ti fi ṣà fihàn à ṣà dá rad ára kan tá wọn èèyàn ń gbé lá rugẹ.
english_text: In Akansociety, emissaries or spokesmen for traditional rulers are well versed in the eloquent use of proverbs, and they also carry a staff of office with motifs espousing some cherished value of the people.

yoruba_text: Bó bá jẹ́ bẹ́ẹ̀, gbé òweAkankan yẹ̀ wò, ìyẹn òwe tó sọ pé: “Ìgbéyà wó kì í ṣe ẹmu téèyàn lè tọ́ wò.”
english_text: Then consider this Akanproverb, “Marriage is not palm wine to be tasted.”

yoruba_text: Ilé Ẹ̀kọ́ ní Áfíríkà Mo jẹ́ ọmọ ìbílẹ̀Akantí ó ti jàǹfà àní lá ti inú ilé ẹ̀kọ́ ìbílẹ̀ ti ilẹ̀ Áfíríkà à ti ilé ẹ̀kọ́ ní ìlà nà ti Ìwọ̀ Oòrùn ayé, mo sì gbá dùn ọ̀rọ̀ ẹ̀kọ́ yín náà, “Ilé Ẹ̀kọ́ ní Africa—Kí Ni Ó Fi Kọ́ni?”
english_text: African School I am an Akanwho has benefited from both the traditional African school and Western schools, and I enjoyed your article “The African School—What Did It Teach?”

yoruba_text: Àwọn Òwe Ẹ̀yàAkanÒwe Tó Ń Gbé Àṣà Ìbílẹ̀ Lá rugẹ
english_text: Akan Proverbs —A Mirror on Social Norms

yoruba_text: ÒweAkanmìíràn sọ pé: “Kò sí bó o ṣe lè sá tó, o ò lè sá mọ́ Ọlọ́run lọ́wọ́.”
english_text: Another Akanproverb states: “If you run away from God, you are still under him.”

yoruba_text: Àwọn ẹ̀yàAkantó wà ní orílẹ̀-èdè Gá nà máa ń lo òwe kan dá ad áa, èyí tó ń sọ bí òwe ṣe ṣe pà tàkì tó, wọ́n máa ń sọ pé: “Àà bọ̀ ọ̀rọ̀ là ń sọ fún ọmọlúwà bí, tó bá dénú rẹ̀ á di odindi.”
english_text: The importance of proverbs, or proverbial sayings, is captured in this proverb, well-known to the Akanpeople of Ghana: “A wise person is spoken to in proverbs, not in prose.”

yoruba_text: Gẹ́gẹ́ bíi ti à wọn òwe tó jẹ́ ti à ṣà ìṣẹ̀dá lẹ̀ mìíràn, à wọn òweAkanjẹ́ ibi ìṣúra fún à wọn à ṣà à ti ìlà nà ìwà híhù lá wùjọ.
english_text: As is true of proverbs from other cultures, Akanproverbs are a repository of social norms and values.

yoruba_text: Àmọ́, ẹ jẹ́ ká ṣà yẹ̀wò à wọn òweAkanbíi mélòó kan.
english_text: But let us take a look at some Akanproverbs.

yoruba_text: Àmọ́ o, bó o bá fẹ́ kí ẹnì kan tó jẹ́ ẹ̀yàAkanm áa pa òwe tẹ̀léra-tẹ̀léra, ó lè fi ẹyọ kan ṣoṣo dá ọ lóhùn, kó sọ pé, “Èèyàn ò lè lá làá lá ìjẹ́ pé ó sùn.”
english_text: However, if you want an Akanto recite a string of proverbs, you might succeed in getting only one, “There cannot be a dream where there is no sleep.”

yoruba_text: Bí à pẹẹrẹ, níhìn-ín ní Gá nà, oríṣi aṣọ tí ń jẹ́ dansenkran ni ó wọ́pọ̀ lá àárín à wọn obìnrin tí ń sọ èdèAkan.
english_text: Here in Ghana, for example, the dansenkran style was popular among Akan-speaking women.

yoruba_text: Nílẹ̀ Gá nà, òwe sá bà máa ń fẹ̀rí hàn pé Ọlọ́run wà, èyí sì máa ń jẹ yọ nínú ọ̀pọ̀ òweAkan.
english_text: In Ghana, proverbial sayings often acknowledge the existence of God, and this is reflected in many Akanproverbs.

yoruba_text: Ọ̀pọ̀ òwe ń fi hàn pé à wọn baba ń lá à wọn ẹ̀yàAkanm áa ń fara balẹ̀ kí yè sí à wọn èèyàn à tà wọn ẹranko.
english_text: A host of proverbial sayings testify to the keen observations that Akanancestors made of people and animals.

yoruba_text: akanalakasaàrùn búburú kan
english_text: cancer

yoruba_text: Tabi boya iwọ nilati gun “iyẹfun daradara,” bii iru eyi ti Sara lo lati fi ṣe “akara” fun awọn angẹli ti wọn gbé ara wọ̀ tabi eyi ti awọn ọmọ Israeli lò ninu ọrẹ-ẹbọ ohun jijẹ si Jehofa.
english_text: Or you might grind “fine flour,” such as Sarah used to make “roundcakes” for materialized angels or that Israelites used in grain offerings to Jehovah.

yoruba_text: Wọn tun duro fun ajọdunAkaraAlaiwu ọlọjọ meje ti o tẹle e, eyi ti wọn kà sí apakan asiko Irekọja.
english_text: They also stay for the following seven-day Festival of Unfermented Cakes, which they consider part of the Passover season.

yoruba_text: Iru awọnakaratito bi roboto bẹẹ ni a lè dín lori awọn okuta tabi agbada, gẹgẹ bi obinrin naa ti ń ṣe.
english_text: Such large, roundcakescould be baked on stones or iron griddles, as the woman is doing.

yoruba_text: Sibẹ, ninu aini gidigidi rẹ̀ paapaa, ó muratan lati ṣeakarafun Elija lakọọkọ, ni gbigbẹkẹle ileri rẹ̀ pe Jehofa yoo pa ipese ikoko òróró ati ikoko ìyẹ̀fun rẹ̀ mọ́ niwọn ìgbà ti aini bá wà.
english_text: Yet, even in her extreme need, she was willing to makebreadfor Elijah first, trusting in his promise that Jehovah would keep her jar of oil and her jar of flour supplied as long as there was a need.

yoruba_text: Ó tumọ si jijẹ ẹran atiakarati awọn ẹyẹ ìwo gbé wá fun un—awọn ẹyẹ ti ń jẹ oku ẹran ti a kà sí alaimọ ninu Ofin Mose—ati níní igbẹkẹle ninu Jehofa pe iru ẹran bẹẹ kì í ṣe oku ẹran ṣugbọn ẹran ti a ti dú lọna bibojumu ni ibamu pẹlu ofin.
english_text: It meant eating meat andbreadcarried to him by ravens —carrion-eating birds deemed unclean in the Mosaic Law— and trusting in Jehovah that such meat was not carrion but meat that had been properly bled according to law.

yoruba_text: “ENIYAN ko le walaaye nipaakaranikan.”
english_text: “MAN cannot live onbreadalone.”

yoruba_text: Gẹgẹ bi Jesu Kristi ti wi, “eniyan ki yoo walaaye nipaakaranikan, bikoṣe nipa gbogbo ọ̀rọ̀ ti o ti ẹnu Ọlọrun jade wá.”—Matteu 4:4.
english_text: As Jesus Christ said, “man must live, not onbreadalone, but on every utterance coming forth through Jehovah's mouth.”—Matthew 4:4.

yoruba_text: “Abigẹli si yara, ó sì mu igba iṣuakaraati igo ọti waini meji, ati agutan marun-un, ti a ti sè, ati oṣuwọn agbado yíyan marun-un, ati ọgọrun-un ìdì à jà rà gbigbẹ, ati igbaa karaeso ọpọtọ, ó sì dì wọn ru kẹtẹkẹtẹ.
english_text: “Abigail hastened and took two hundredloavesofbreadand two large jars of wine and five sheep dressed and five seah measures of roasted grain and a hundred cakes of raisins and two hundredcakesof pressed figs and put them upon the asses.

yoruba_text: Èròjà beryllium, mẹ́tá àlì kan tí ó fúyẹ́ gẹgẹ tí a ń mú já de ní onírúurú ọ̀nà, ni a ń lò nínú à wọn ilé-iṣẹ́ ọkọ̀ òfuurufú, nígbà tí a bá sì ti mú un gba abẹ́ ìtà nṣ án olóró gíga kọjá tán, a ń lò ó ní à wọn ibùdó ìpèsè agbá ra iná mà nàm áná alá gb ára á tọ́míìkì.
english_text: Beryllium, a remarkably light metal produced by various processes, is used in the aircraft industry and, when irradiated, in nuclear power stations.

yoruba_text: Ìwé ìròyìn The European ṣà làyé pé: “Eruku èròjà beryllium, à ní nígbà tí kò bá ti inú ìtà nṣ án olóró gíga wá pà ápàá, jẹ́ ọ̀kan lá ra à wọn pàǹtírí ilé-iṣẹ́ ẹ̀rọ tí ó lóró jùlọ tí a tíì mọ̀ rí.”
english_text: “Berylliumdust, even when not irradiated,” noted The European, “is one of the most toxic forms of industrial waste known.”

yoruba_text: Ìwé ìròyìn náà The European ṣà làyé pé: “Àyẹ̀wò tí a ń ṣe déédéé èyí tí a pà ṣẹ rẹ̀ lẹ́yìn ikú obìnrin à dúgbò kan tí má jèlé èròjà berylliumṣekúpa ní oṣù méjì sẹ́yìn ṣí i payá pé ìwọ̀n ìtà nṣ án olóró gíga tí ó fi 100 ìgbà pọ̀ ju ti à wọn wọnnì tí ń bẹ ní agbègbè à yíká náà lọ ń bẹ ní ibi ìgbafà ájì náà.”
english_text: The newspaper The European explained: “Routine checks ordered after the death of a local woman fromberylliumpoisoning two months ago revealed levels of radioactivity at the picnic site which were 100 times higher than those in the surrounding area.”

yoruba_text: Gẹ́gẹ́ bí ẹ̀rí ti fihàn, ilé-iṣẹ́ kan tí ń pèsè èròjà berylliumti da à wọn pàǹtírí tí ó já de wá lá ti inú ìmúkọjá lá bẹ́ ìtà nṣ án olóró gíga náà sórí tà bí sẹ́bàá agbègbè ìgbafà ájì náà.
english_text: Evidently a factory producingberylliumhad discarded waste from the dangerous irradiating process on or near the picnic area.

yoruba_text: Lá tàrí èyí, ó kùnà lá ti má ab áa nìṣó lá ti jẹ́ olóòótọ́ sí Ọlọ́run.

yoruba_text: Ìwà Anna tún wú olùkọ́ náà lórí, ó sì gbóríyìn fun un níwá jú à wọn ọmọ kí lá àsì tó kù to rí pé ó jẹ́ ọmọlúwà bí à tibóṣe máa ń múra níwọ̀ntúnwọ̀nsì.
english_text: The teacher was also impressed with Anna's behavior, praising her in front of the whole class for her goodmannersand modest dress.

yoruba_text: Fún à pẹẹrẹ, òkìkí Nostradamus, awòrà wọ̀ tó jẹ́ ọmọ ilẹ̀ Faransé nì, ṣì ń kàn títí di ìsinsìnyí, bótilẹ̀ jẹ́ pé ọ̀pọ̀ ọ̀rúndún ti kọjá tó ti kú.
english_text: For example, French astrologer Nostradamus continues to be popular, though hehas been dead for centuries.

yoruba_text: Kà kà bẹ́ẹ̀, ṣe lòun ń “wà lá àyè nìṣó”bótiẹ̀ jẹ́ pé ipò tirẹ̀ yà tọ̀ sí ti ọ̀pọ̀ jù lọ èèyàn ìgbà ayé rẹ̀.
english_text: He survived Jerusalem's destruction, thoughhis personal situation was different from most.

yoruba_text: Bóyá o tiẹ̀ ti ń sọ lọ́kàn rẹ pé, 'Bóṣe dà bíi pé Jèhófà ò ṣe nǹkan kan nípa à dá nwò mi yìí, ǹjẹ́ èyí ò fi hàn pé kò mọ ohun tí mò ń dojú kọ tà bí pé kò tiẹ̀ bìkí tà nípa mi?'
english_text: Perhaps you wonder, 'Does the fact that Jehovah appears not to have done anything about my trial mean that he is unaware of my situation or that he does not care about me?'

yoruba_text: Pabanbarì ẹ̀ ni pé kò sẹ́ni tó máa sọ pé òun ò mọbóṣe máa ń ṣèèyàn nígbà téèyàn ẹni bá kú.
english_text: And who of us has not experienced deep pain and emptiness after losing a loved one in death?

yoruba_text: Bí à pẹẹrẹ, bóo bá ń fẹ́ ká wọn èèyàn máa fojú à gbà lagbà wò ẹ́, ìyẹn lè jẹ́ kó o bẹ̀rẹ̀ sí kọ à wọn ìlà nà rere tá wọn òbí ẹ fi tọ́ ẹ dà gbà sílẹ̀.
english_text: For example, the longing foryourown identity could drive you to turn against good values you've been taught at home.

yoruba_text: Bí èdè yìí ṣe máa ń dún téèyàn bá ń sọ ọ́, bóṣe jẹ́ pé ń ṣe là wọn fá wẹ̀lì tẹ̀ lé ara wọn (odidi fá wẹ̀lì má rùn-ún lè wà nínú ọ̀rọ̀ kan ṣoṣo), à tibóṣe jẹ́ pé ìwọ̀nba kọ́ń sónáǹtì díẹ̀ ló ní mú kó fẹ́ sú à wọn míṣọ́nná rì náà.
english_text: The exhaling sounds of the language interrupted by glottal stops, itsnumerous successive vowels (as many as five in a single word), anditsrare consonants drove the missionaries to despair.

yoruba_text: Bótilẹ̀ jẹ́ pé ohun tó ṣe é yìí le gan-an, tí à wọn dókí tà kan sì sọ pé tí wọ́n ò bá fẹ́ kó kú, ó yẹ kí wọ́n fa ẹ̀jẹ̀ sí i lá ra, à wọn tó ń tọ́jú rẹ̀ sọ pé ohun tó kọ sínú ìwé yẹn là wọn máa tẹ̀ lé.
english_text: Although hiscondition was serious and some doctors felt that to save his life, blood transfusion was necessary, the medical staff was prepared to honor his wishes.

yoruba_text: Mo bẹ̀ ẹ́ pé kí ó bá mi tún à wọn ẹsẹ̀ mi tí ó ti rún gbé sípòbóti yẹ.
english_text: I asked her to adjust the position of my legs, astheywere mangled.

yoruba_text: Ẹnì kan tó nífẹ̀ẹ́ rẹ lè fòye mọ ohun tó wà lọ́kàn rẹ gan-an kó wá jẹ́ kó o mọ̀ pé lá ra ohun tó o máa kọ́ níléèwé nibóo ṣe lè ní ìforítì. Ó sì yẹ kó o ní ìforítì tó o bá máa fi gbogbo agbá ra rẹ sin Jèhófà.—Sm.
english_text: A person who loves you may discern your motives and help you to realize that school can help you to learn not to give up easily, a vital quality if you want to serve Jehovah fully. —Ps.

yoruba_text: (Sá àmù 78:41) Ẹ sì wá wobóṣe máa dùn ún tó nígbà tá wọn ọ̀dọ́ tí wọ́n fi “ìbá wí à ti ìlà nà èrò orí Jèhófà” kọ́ bá ń yọ́ à wọn nǹkan tí kò dáa ṣe!—Éfésù 6:4.
english_text: (Psalm 78:41)Howpained he must be today when youths reared “in the discipline and mental-regulating of Jehovah” secretly do wrong things! —Ephesians 6:4.

yoruba_text: (Mátíù 28:19, 20) Àwọn ọ̀rọ̀ wọ̀nyẹn bá a mu gan-an ni, níwọ̀nbóti jẹ́ pé orílẹ̀-èdè ogun ni a rán àwọn akẹ́kọ̀ọ́yege wọ̀nyí lọ láti lọ máa sìn
english_text: Gẹ́gẹ́bóṣe rí nígbà ayé Jeremáyà, Jèhófà, Ọlọ́run ayérayé nìkan ní Orísun omi ààyè.As wasthe casein Jeremiah’s day, the eternal God, Jehovah, continues to be the only Source of life-giving waters.jw2019

yoruba_text: (Mátíù 28:19, 20) Àwọn ọ̀rọ̀ wọ̀nyẹn bá a mu gan-an ni, níwọ̀nbóti jẹ́ pé orílẹ̀-èdè ogun ni a rán àwọn akẹ́kọ̀ọ́yege wọ̀nyí lọ láti lọ máa sìn
english_text: (Matthew 28:19, 20) How appropriate that was,sincethe graduates are being sent to serve in 20 different countries!

english_text: As wasthe casein Jeremiah’s day, the eternal God, Jehovah, continues to be the only Source of life-giving waters.

yoruba_text: Bótilẹ̀ jẹ́ pé mo mọ ojú pàtàkì tí Ọlọ́run fi ń wo ara èèyàn, síbẹ̀ mi ò yé ṣe é
english_text: I knew of God’s high regard for the human body, but even this did not deter me.” —Jennifer, 20.

yoruba_text: Bóṣe wà nínú Ẹ́kísódù 23: 9, báwo ni Ọlọ́run ṣe fẹ́ káwọn ọmọ Ísírẹ́lì máa ṣe sáwọn àjèjì, kí sì nìdí
english_text: Ó dájú pébóo ṣe fi hàn pé ọ̀ràn wọn jẹ ẹ́ lógún máa wú wọn lórí.No doubt they’ll be pleased thatyoucare enough to ask about their life.jw2019

yoruba_text: Bóṣe wà nínú Ẹ́kísódù 23: 9, báwo ni Ọlọ́run ṣe fẹ́ káwọn ọmọ Ísírẹ́lì máa ṣe sáwọn àjèjì, kí sì nìdí
english_text: Accordingto Exodus 23:9, how were God’s ancient people expected to treat foreigners, and why?

yoruba_text: Ó dájú pébóo ṣe fi hàn pé ọ̀ràn wọn jẹ ẹ́ lógún máa wú wọn lórí
english_text: No doubt they’ll be pleased thatyoucare enough to ask about their life.

yoruba_text: (Diutarónómì 23:12-14)Bótiẹ̀ jẹ́ pé kò rọrùn fún wọn láti tẹ̀ lé àwọn òfin yìí torí pé ibùdó náà tóbi, àmọ́ ó dájú pé èyí ràn wọ́n lọ́wọ́ láti dènà àwọn àrùn bí ibà táífọ́ọ̀dù àti kọ́lẹ́rà
english_text: A jọ sọ̀rọ̀ lórí bí Jésù ṣe jẹ́ Júù àti lórí kókó náà pé,bótilẹ̀ jẹ́ pé Júù ni mí, mo ti di ọ̀kan lára àwọn Ẹlẹ́rìí Jèhófà.We talked about Jesus’ being a Jew and about the fact that eventhoughI was Jewish, I had become one of Jehovah’s Witnesses.jw2019

yoruba_text: (Diutarónómì 23:12-14)Bótiẹ̀ jẹ́ pé kò rọrùn fún wọn láti tẹ̀ lé àwọn òfin yìí torí pé ibùdó náà tóbi, àmọ́ ó dájú pé èyí ràn wọ́n lọ́wọ́ láti dènà àwọn àrùn bí ibà táífọ́ọ̀dù àti kọ́lẹ́rà

english_text: 8BóO Ṣe Lè Di Ọ̀kan Lára Àwọn Ọmọ Ọlọ́run8 Becoming One of God’s Childrenjw2019

english_text: She insisted that I play boules (a French bowling game) with him eventhoughit was not my favorite game.

english_text: 8 Becoming One of God’s Children

english_text: AlthoughI still yearned to serve as a full-time minister, how could I do so?

yoruba_text: (Gálátíà 6:10; Ìṣe 16:14-18)Bótilẹ̀ rí bẹ́ẹ̀, àwọn Kristẹni tòótọ́ máa ń yàgò fún lílọ́wọ́ nínú ìjọsìn èké, títí kan ohunkóhun tó bá jẹ mọ́ ṣíṣàjẹ́
english_text: Bótilẹ̀ jẹ́ pé Mósè àti Áárónì ni wọ́n dojú ìráhùn wọn kọ, Jèhófà wò ó pé òun Ọlọ́run gan-an ni wọ́n ń ráhùn sí.Althoughtheir complaints were directed against Moses and Aaron, in Jehovah’s eyes the real target of their discontent was God himself.jw2019

english_text: Althoughtheir complaints were directed against Moses and Aaron, in Jehovah’s eyes the real target of their discontent was God himself.

yoruba_text: Àfibóṣe di pé oko ọkùnrin ọlọ́rọ̀ kan tó ń jẹ́ Bóásì ló ti ráyè pèéṣẹ́, Bóásì sì jẹ́ mọ̀lẹ́bí Elimélékì ọkọ Náómì tó ti kú

english_text: So I returned to my family in Minnesota, all of whom were now baptized and associated with the Detroit Lakes Congregation.

english_text: But I am pleased that in Detroit Lakes, where all of us started out as Jehovah's Witnesses years ago, I have a spiritual family of more than 90 Christian brothers and sisters.

english_text: If you do not replenish the water that is lost through perspiration, the heart has to work harder to circulate the blood.

yoruba_text: Tún gbìyà njú ọ̀nà míì. Bí à pẹẹrẹ, dípòtí wàá fi bi ọmọbìnrin rẹ nípa bí ìgbòkègbodò rẹ̀ ọjọ́ yẹn ṣe rí, ń ṣe ni kí ìwọ sọ bí ìgbòkègbodò tìrẹ fúnra rẹ ṣe rí lọ́jọ́ yẹn, kó o wá wò ó bóyá òun náà á sọ̀rọ̀.
english_text: For example, instead ofasking your daughter about her day, tell her how your day was and see if she responds.

english_text: Rather thantell your classmates what they should or should not believe, state confidently what you believe and why you feel that your conclusions are reasonable.

yoruba_text: (Ìṣe 20:29, 30) Ó ní lá ti bá à wọn Onísìn Júù jiyàn, à wọn tí wọ́n ń wá ọ̀nà lá ti fi ìsìnrú lá bẹ́ Òfin Mósè, tí a ti múṣẹ nínú Kristi, dípòòmìnira alá àlà ti òfin Kristi.

english_text: Rather thanjudging such ones as never likely to become worshipers of Jehovah, we should have a positive attitude, “for even we were once senseless, disobedient, [and] being misled.”

yoruba_text: Dípòká wọn ìsìn yìí so à wọn èèyàn pọ̀ kí ìmọ̀ wọn lè ṣọ̀kan, ìpínyà ni wọ́n ń dá sílẹ̀ tí wọn ò sì jẹ́ ká wọn èèyàn mọrú ẹni tí Ọlọ́run jẹ́ gan-an à ti bó ṣe yẹ ká sìn ín.
english_text: On thecontrary, they have divided mankind and painted a confusing picture of who God is and how to worship him.

english_text: (Revelation 17:6, 16; 18:7, 8) When the “scarlet-colored wild beast”attacks the religious harlot, “the disgusting thing” will be standing in a menacing way in Christendom's so-called holy place.

yoruba_text: (Aísá yà 10:5; Ìṣípayá 18:2-8) Àwọn orílẹ̀-èdè tó jẹ́ ara Ìparapọ̀ Àwọn Orílẹ̀-Èdè, ìyẹn à jọ tí Ìṣípayá ṣà pèjúwe pé ó jẹ́ ẹranko ẹhà nnà alá wọ̀ rírẹ̀dòdò, tó ní orí méje à ti ìwo mẹ́wàá, ni yóò jẹ́ “ọ̀pá” yẹn.—Ìṣípayá 17:3, 15-17.
english_text: (Isaiah 10:5; Revelation 18:2-8) That “rod” will be member nations of the United Nations —an organization pictured in Revelation as a seven-headed, ten-horned, scarlet-colored wild beast. —Revelation 17:3, 15-17.

yoruba_text: 'Bí à wọn ẹ̀ṣẹ̀ yín tilẹ̀ rí bí aṣọ rírẹ̀dòdò, a ó sọ wọ́n di funfun gẹ́gẹ́ bí ìrì dídì.'”
english_text: 'Though the sins of you people should prove to be as scarlet, they will be made white just like snow.'”

english_text: What does the angel call the symbolic scarlet-colored wild beast, and in what way does it spring from the seven?

yoruba_text: Ìran kọkà nlá ṣà péjúwe rẹ̀ gẹ́gẹ́ bí obìnrin “aṣẹ́wó ń lá” kan “tí ó jókòó lórí ẹranko ẹhà nnà alá wọ̀ rírẹ̀dòdò.”
english_text: The 11th vision portrays her as a “great harlot” —an immoral woman— “sitting upon a scarlet-colored wild beast.”

yoruba_text: Ẹranko ẹhà nnà ìṣà pẹẹrẹ, alá wọ̀ rírẹ̀dòdò, à ti ìwo mẹ́wàá rẹ̀ ni “yóò... sọ [Bá bílónì Ńlá] di ìparundahoro à ti ìhòòhò, wọn yóò sì jẹ à wọn ibi kìkìdá ẹran ara rẹ̀ tán, wọn yóò sì fi iná sun ún pá táp átá.”
english_text: The symbolicscarlet-colored wild beast and its ten horns “will make [Babylon the Great] devastated and naked, and will eat up her fleshy parts and will completely burn her with fire.”

yoruba_text: 17 Ìparun Babiloni Ńlá ni a ṣà pèjúwe kedere nínú ìwé Ìfihàn: “Àwọn ìwo mẹ́wàá tí ìwọ rí [à wọn 'ọba' tí ń ṣà kóso ní à kókò òpin], à ti ẹranko ẹhà nnà náà [ẹranko ẹhà nnà alá wọ̀ rírẹ̀dòdò, tí ó dúró fún ètò-à jọ Ìparapọ̀ Àwọn Orílẹ̀-Èdè], à wọn wọ̀nyí yóò kórìíra aṣẹ́wó náà wọn yóò sì sọ ọ́ di ìparun-dahoro à ti ìhòòhò, wọn yóó sì jẹ à wọn ibi ẹran-ara rẹ̀ wọn yóó sì fi iná sun ún pá táp átá.”
english_text: 17 The destruction of Babylon the Great is graphically described in the book of Revelation: “The ten horns that you saw [the 'kings' ruling in the time of the end], and the wild beast [the scarlet-colored wild beast, representing the United Nations organization], these will hate the harlot and will make her devastated and naked, and will eat up her fleshy parts and will completely burn her with fire.”

english_text: + Let everyone with a willing heart+ bring a contribution for Jehovah: gold, silver, copper, 6 blue thread, purple wool, scarlet material, fine linen, goat hair,+ 7 ram skins dyed red, sealskins, acacia wood, 8 oil for the lamps, balsam for the anointing oil and for the perfumed incense,+ 9 onyx stones, and other stones for setting in the ephʹod+ and the breastpiece.

yoruba_text: 13 Wò ó, mo ti rán ọkùnrin ọ̀já fáfá oníṣẹ́ ọnà kan sí ọ, ó ní òye, Hiramu-á bì+ ni orúkọ rẹ̀, 14 ó jẹ́ ọmọ obìnrin kan tó wá lá tinú ẹ̀yà Dá nì, à mọ́ tí bà bá rẹ̀ jẹ́ ará Tírè; ó já fá fá nínú iṣẹ́ ọnà wúrà, fà dákà, bà bà, irin, òkúta, igi gẹdú, òwú alá wọ̀ pọ́pù, fọ́nr án òwú alá wọ̀ búlúù, aṣọ à tà tà à ti aṣọ rírẹ̀dòdò.
english_text: 13 Now I am sending a skilled craftsman, endowed with understanding, Hiʹram-aʹbi,+ 14 who is the son of a Danʹite woman but whose father was a man of Tyre; he has experience in working in gold, silver, copper, iron, stones, timbers, purple wool, blue thread, fine fabric, and crimson.

yoruba_text: Àwọn ata rírẹ̀dòdò
english_text: Colorful peppers

yoruba_text: (Aísá yà 55:6, 7) Nínú ìwé Aísá yà 1:18, Jèhófà sọ pé: “Bí à wọn ẹ̀ṣẹ̀ yín tilẹ̀ rí bí aṣọ rírẹ̀dòdò[tí wọ́n wúwo, tí wọ́n lá gb ára gan-an], a ó sọ wọ́n di funfun gẹ́gẹ́ bí ìrì dídì [a óò mú wọn kúrò pá táp átá].”
english_text: (Isaiah 55:6, 7) At Isaiah 1:18, Jehovah says: “Though the sins of you people should prove to be as scarlet[weighty, serious], they will be made white just like snow [completely cleansed].”

yoruba_text: Ara irú à wọn ìṣá wùrú òkun kan ni wọ́n ti ń rí oríṣiríṣi aró bí aró alá wọ̀ à lùkò, alá wọ̀ búlúù à ti alá wọ̀ pípọ́ndòdò.
english_text: The combination of pigments from various murex sea snails could produce shades and colors ranging from royal purple to blue tocrimsonred.

yoruba_text: Ki là wa Ẹlẹ́rìí Jèhófà ń ṣe níto rí rírí tá a rí ìtumọ̀ ohun ìjìnlẹ̀ aṣẹ́wó ń lá à ti ẹranko ẹhà nnà alá wọ̀ rírẹ̀dòdòn áà?
english_text: And how do Jehovah's Witnesses respond to the unraveling of the mystery of the great harlot and of the scarlet-colored wildbeast?

yoruba_text: Níto rí náà, à jọ Ìparapọ̀ Àwọn Orílẹ̀-Èdè ni ẹranko ẹhà nnà alá wọ̀ rírẹ̀dòdòtó sọ jí.
english_text: The UN, then, is actually a revival of the scarlet-colored wild beast.

yoruba_text: 21 Bẹ́ẹ̀ ni, à wọn orílẹ̀-èdè máa lo ẹranko ẹhà nnà alá wọ̀ rírẹ̀dòdòn áà, ìyẹn Ìparapọ̀ Àwọn Orílẹ̀-Èdè, lá ti pa Bá bílónì Ńlá run.
english_text: 21 Yes, the nations will use the scarlet-colored wildbeast, the United Nations, in destroying Babylon the Great.

yoruba_text: 7 Ní bá yìí, fi ọkùnrin oníṣẹ́ ọnà kan rá nṣẹ́ sí mi, tó já fá fá nínú iṣẹ́ ọnà wúrà, fà dákà, bà bà,+ irin, òwú alá wọ̀ pọ́pù, òwú rírẹ̀dòdòà ti fọ́nr án òwú alá wọ̀ búlúù, tó sì mọ bí a ti ń fín à wọn iṣẹ́ ọnà.
english_text: 7 Now send me a craftsman who is skilled in working in gold, silver, copper,+ iron, purple wool, crimson, andblue thread and who knows how to cut engravings.

yoruba_text: Àwọn tí a fi aṣọ rírẹ̀dòdòtọ́ dà gbà+ ti wá ń lọ sínú òkìtì eérú.
english_text: Those who werebroughtup wearing scarlet+ have embraced ash heaps.

yoruba_text: Mo sì rí obìnrin kan tó jókòó lórí ẹranko alá wọ̀ rírẹ̀dòdòtó kún fún à wọn orúkọ tó jẹ́ ọ̀rọ̀ òdì, ó ní orí méje à ti ìwo mẹ́wàá.
english_text: And I saw a woman sitting on a scarlet-colored wild beast that was full of blasphemous names and that had seven heads and ten horns.

yoruba_text: Bíbélì sá bà máa ń sọ ọ́ pé wọ́n fi à wọ̀ búlúù, à wọ̀ à lùkò à ti à wọ̀ pípọ́ndòdòpa aṣọ tà bí fọ́nr án òwú lá ró.
english_text: Blue, purple, andcrimsonare frequently mentioned in the Bible as dyes for fabrics.

yoruba_text: Lá ti ojú fèrèsé rẹ̀, ó gbọ́dọ̀ so okùn rírẹ̀dòdòtí ó fi sọ à wọn amí náà kalẹ̀ lẹ́yìn odi Jeriko rọ̀.
english_text: From her window, she must hang the scarlet cord used to lower the spies to the ground outside the walls of Jericho.

yoruba_text: 8 Ó wá mú kí ẹni tó ń kó iṣẹ́ sí aṣọ ṣe aṣọ ìgbà yà,+ bí wọ́n ṣe ṣe éfódì, ó lo wúrà, fọ́nr án òwú alá wọ̀ búlúù, òwú alá wọ̀ pọ́pù, òwú alá wọ̀ rírẹ̀dòdòà ti aṣọ ọ̀gbọ̀ lílọ́ tó dáa.
english_text: 8 Then he made the breastpiece+ with the workmanship of an embroiderer, like the workmanship of the ephʹod, out of gold, blue thread, purple wool, scarlet material, andfine twisted linen.

yoruba_text: Aṣẹ́wó yìí gun ẹranko ẹhà nnà alá wọ̀ rírẹ̀dòdòkan tó ní orí méje à ti ìwo mẹ́wàá.
english_text: The harlot is ridingascarlet-colored wild beast that has seven heads and ten horns.

english_text: Greekssettledthe city, but the Lydians destroyed it in about 580 B. C. E.

english_text: Later, when the Israelites entered Canaan and cameagainst Jericho, Jehovah miraculously caused the collapse of Jericho's walls.

english_text: Joshua 6:26 states: “Joshua had an oath pronounced at that particular time, saying: 'Cursed may the man be before Jehovah who gets up and doesbuildthis city, even Jericho.

yoruba_text: Àmọ́ tó bá di ọ̀ràn ìjọsìn wọn ojoojúmọ́, síná gọ́gù à dúgbò ni wọ́n máa ń lò, bóyá wọ́n ń gbé ní Palẹ́sìnì tà bí wọ́n ń gbé ní ọ̀kan lá ra ọ̀pọ̀ ìlú tí à wọn Júù tẹ̀dósí nílẹ̀ òkèèrè.
english_text: But for their day-to-day worship, the local synagogue served their needs, whether they lived in Palestine or in one of the many Jewish colonies thatwereestablished abroad.

yoruba_text: Ní ọ̀pọ̀ ọ̀rúndún ṣá ájú Ìkún Omi, iye à wọn èèyàn tó wà lá yé ti pọ̀ débi pé Kéènì, ọmọ Ádá mù, tẹ ìlú ń lá kandó, tó pè ní Énọ́kù.
english_text: Many centuries before the Flood, earth's population had grown to such an extent that Adam's son Cain was able tobuilda city, which he called Enoch.

yoruba_text: Ìwé Hébérù 11:10 sọ nípa Ábúrá mù pé: “Ó ń dúró de ìlú ń lá tí ó ní à wọn ìpìlẹ̀ tòótọ́, ìlú ń lá tí olùtẹ̀dóà ti olùṣẹ̀dá rẹ̀ jẹ́ Ọlọ́run.”
english_text: Hebrews 11:10 says of Abram: “He was awaiting the city having real foundations, the builderandmaker of which city is God.”

english_text: 24 Afterward Ben-haʹdad the king of Syria gathered all his army* together and went up andbesieged Sa·marʹi·a.

yoruba_text: Ẹ̀rí fi hàn pé òkúta ẹfun tí wọ́n rí yìí ló mú kí wọ́n tẹ ìlú ná àdósíbẹ̀, níto rí ìyẹn fi hàn pé omi wà lá gbègbè náà, èyí tó ṣe pà tàkì ní à gbègbè tí odò ń lá jìn sí.
english_text: The site was evidently chosen because the limestone layer guaranteed the presence of a natural water supply, important in a region far from major rivers.

yoruba_text: Àwọn ọ̀kẹ́mẹ́tà lá olùgbé erékùṣù tító bi jùlọ ṣìkejì ti Europe yìí jẹ́ ìran-à tẹ̀lé à wọn Viki ng, tí wọ́n tẹ̀dósíhìn-ín ní nǹkan tí ó ju ẹ̀ẹ́dẹ́gbẹ̀fà ọdún lọ sẹ́yìn.
english_text: The 260,000 inhabitants of this second-largest island of Europe are descendants of the Vikings, who settledheremore than 1,100 years ago.

yoruba_text: Ìjì “kamikaze” ń tọ́ka sí ẹ̀fúùfù tí ó jà ní ọdún 1274 à ti 1281 tí ó fọ́ ọ̀pọ̀ lá ra ọ̀wọ́ ọkọ̀ ogun ojú omi ti à wọn Mongol tí wọ́n dósí etíkun Japan túútúú, tó sì ti pa bẹ́ẹ̀ mú kí wọ́n kógun wọn lọ.
english_text: Kamikaze refers to the storms in 1274 and 1281 that twice destroyed much of theinvading Mongol armadas off the Japanese coast, thus forcing them to withdraw.

yoruba_text: ABÚLÉ kan tí wọ́n tẹ̀dósórí ilẹ̀ onílẹ̀ (èyí tẹ́ ẹ̀ ń wò lókè yìí) ní ìká ngun ìlú Lima, lórílẹ̀-èdè Peru, ni obìnrin kan tó ń jẹ́ Consuelo à tà wọn ọmọ rẹ̀ mẹ́tà lá ń gbé.
english_text: CONSUELO and her 13 children live in a squatter village (shown above) on the outskirts of Lima, Peru.

yoruba_text: Lẹ́yìn náà, Kéènì lọ tẹ ìlú ń lá kandó, ó sì sọ ọ́ ní orúkọ ọmọ rẹ̀.
english_text: Cain later went on tobuilda city, naming it for his son.

yoruba_text: Àbá jáde rẹ̀ ni pé, Gaul wá dà bí èso à jà rà tó ti pọ́n, tó ń retí pé kí ọ̀kan lá ra à wọn ẹ̀yà tó tẹ̀dósí à à là ilẹ̀ náà wá já òun.
english_text: In consequence, Gaul was like a ripe fig waiting to be plucked by one of the tribessettledwithin its borders.

yoruba_text: Níwọ̀n bí “Lọ́ọ̀tì [ti] yan gbogbo Àgbègbè Jọ́dá nì fún ara rẹ̀” tó sì tẹ̀dósẹ́bàá Sódómù, ó ní lá ti jẹ́ pé ibẹ̀ yẹn ni ibi tó dá ra jù lọ tó un à ti ìdílé rẹ̀ lè fìdí kalẹ̀ sí.
english_text: It must have seemed to be the perfect place to settle his family, since “Lot chose for himself the whole District of the Jordan” and set upcampnear Sodom.

yoruba_text: A kò lè sọ pà tó ọdún tà bí à kókò tí wọn tẹ ìlú Àkúrẹ́dó, ṣùgbọ́n gẹ́gẹ́ bí Arífá lò (1991) ṣe wòye, ó ní Àkúrẹ́ fẹ́rẹ̀ẹ́ jẹ́ ọ̀kan lá ra à wọn ìlú tó pẹ́ tí wọ́n ti tẹ̀dónílẹ̀ Yorùbá.
english_text: The precise year or time that Akure was first settled is unknown, however according to Arífá lò (1992), Akure is probably one of the earliest settled to wns in Yorubaland.

english_text: Brother Fernandez recalls: “A five-hour flight brought us to the most isolated part of the planet, to a culture enshrouded in mystery.”

yoruba_text: Etíkun yìí tí wọ́n wá ń pè ní Cá diz bá yìí lórílẹ̀-èdè Sípéènì wà lá ra à wọn ìlú ń láń lá tí wọ́n kọ́kọ́ tẹ̀dólá pá Ìlà Oòrùn ilẹ̀ Yúróòpù.
english_text: This port, now known as Cá diz, Spain, became one of the first large cities of Western Europe.
